channel.title: Tapes on My New Hugo Site
channel.description: Recent content in Tapes on My New Hugo Site

item.title: A Bigger, Better Tape
item.description: [big]Start the tape: Roughly a year and a half ago, I made a pitch that we were due for a magnetic-tape comeback similar to the one we’ve seen for vinyl. (I titled it after a Frank Turner album, because Frank Turner is cool.) Now, we haven’t seen that magnetic-tape comeback just yet, but it might help if I did my part by highlighting tape-format obscurities.[/big] One of those obscurities worth a mention is the Elcaset, just one of Sony’s many attempts to create a new standard of some kind.

item.title: Tape Deck Heart
item.description: [whitebox] [big]Today in Tedium: When’s the big comeback for magnetic tapes coming around, anyway? These days, vinyl is making a serious comeback with the public. Even Taylor Swift is selling a ton of vinyl records these days. But in a world where streaming and optical discs are more common than ever, the magnetic tape—which arguably has as much nostalgic hipster cachet as the vinyl record, and across a variety of formats at that—hasn’t seen nearly as much love.
